group.label: Please ask around the community for details especially ROAD NAMES and others.

item.label: Highway
Path (foot traffic only)
Bridge
Barrier

select1.label: What type of road is this?

item.label: Trunk (The most important roads in a country's system that aren't motorways)
Primary (The next most important roads in a country's system, ften linking larger towns)
Secondary (major road within city)
Tertiary (The next most important roads in a country's system, ften linking smaller towns and villages)
Unclassified (The least important through roads in a country's system â€“ i.e. minor roads of a lower classification than tertiary, but which serve a purpose other than access to properties)
Residential (Roads which serve as an access to housing, without function of connecting settlements. Often lined with housing)
Service (driveways, access roads)
Path (foot traffic only)
Track (jeep trail)

input.label: Does this road have a name?

select1.label: What is the surface of this road?

item.label: Paved (predominantly paved; i.e., it is covered with paving stones, concrete or bitumen)
Asphalt (short for asphalt concrete - mineral aggregate bound by asphalt)
Concrete (cement based concrete, forming a large surface, typically cast in place and may have predetermined breaking joints)
Unpaved (A feature that is predominantly unsealed (unpaved); i.e., it has a loose covering ranging from compacted stone chippings to earth)
Cobblestone (raw cobblestone of natural, uncut, rounded stones. Unlike pebblestone firmly connected to the ground)
Sand (small to very small fractions (less than 2mm) of rock.)
Gravel (broken/crushed rock with sharp edges, known as ballast on railways. Usually loosely arranged)
Compacted (mixture of larger (e.g., gravel) and smaller (e.g., sand) parts, compacted (e.g., with a roller), so the surface is more stable than loose gravel)
Dirt (gravel is sometimes mistakenly called dirt. Some compacted surfaces are sometimes called "dirt" too, please consider using compacted)
Metal (used for metal surfaced bridges, or for temporary tracks over fields for normal road vehicles or site traffic)
Grass (Grass covered ground. Mostly nice to walk. May turn into surface=dirt or become overgrown and disappear)
Mud (most of the year wet which gives a soft ground with low carrying capacity. Mostly found on wetland like swamps or in tidal areas)
Good (Possible to drive consistently at the speed limit without worrying about imperfections)
Intermediate (Occasional imperfections requiring caution or slow passage)
Bad (Many imperfections, not possible to drive consistently at the speed limit)
Very Bad (Impossible to ever drive at the speed limit, better to use 4-wheel drive)
Horrible (You'll know it when you see it.)
Impassable (In wheeled vehicle)

select1.label: Is it oneway?
select1.hint: (direction of traffic, NOT the number of lane)

item.label: yes
no

select1.label: Is the road is accessible throughout the year?

item.label: yes
no
Only in dry season

select.label: What type of vehicle can be used to access your area?

item.label: Motorbike
Car
Push cart
Truck
Pick up

select1.label: What is the quality of this highway ?

item.label: Grade 1 (usually a paved or sealed surface)
Grade 2 (solid but unpaved. Usually an unpaved track with surface of gravel)
Grade 3 (mostly solid. Even mixture of hard and soft materials)
Grade 4 (mostly soft. Almost always an unpaved track prominently with soil/sand/grass)
Grade 5 (almost always an unimproved track lacking hard materials, same as surrounding soil)

select1.label: What is the difficulty of this path ?

item.label: Hiking (Can be hiked in ordinary sports shoes/trainers, no risk of falling)
Mountain Hking (terrain is steep in places and may have fall hazards)
Demanding Mountain Hiking (Portions of the route exposed with danger of falling. Trail may have unmarked portions and cross fields of loose scree or talus)
Alpine Hiking (terrain quite exposed. Trail may include steep grassy pitches, talus slopes, easy snowfields, or snow-free glacier crossings )
Demanding Alpine Hiking (exposed and demanding terrain. May include steep rock scrambles, glaciers and snowfields with risk of sliding.)
Difficult Alpine Hiking (severe exposure, difficult craggy terain, includes climbing pitches up to UIAA grade II.)

select1.label: How difficult is it to follow the path ?

item.label: Excellent (Unambiguous path or markers everywhere)
Good (Next marker always visible, but sometimes has to be searched for. Basic sense of direction recommended)
Intermediate (track mostly visible, Good sense of direction, map required)
Bad (path sometimes invisible, route partly pathless, orienting skills recommended)
Horrible (often pathless, advanced orientational skills recommended)
No (mostly pathless, excellent orientational skills recommended)

select1.label: What type of bridge is it ?

item.label: Aqueduct (longer structure for carrying a canal or fresh water)
Boardwalk (plank walkway over wet or otherwise difficult terrain usually low to the ground and supported by posts. )
Cantilever (bridge where a span is supported at one end only. Usually the free ends of two spans are fastened to one another giving a longer) clear span between supports.
Covered (covered bridge has a roof and fully or partly enclosed sides usually to protect the bridge deck.
Low Water Crossing (low bridge over a waterway suitable to cross with a vehicle)
Ford (shallow spot in a waterway suitable to cross with a vehicle)
Trestle (composed of a series of short spans where each span is supported by a rigid frame usually called a "bent" rather than a pier.
Viaduct (composed of a series of spans often short relative to its overall length)
Baily Bridge (often left over from WW2)
Unknown bridge type

input.label: Name of this bridge if it has one
Please take a GPS location on this bridge

group.label: Is there a barrier blocking this highway ?

select1.label: What type of barrier is it ?

item.label: Block (large solid immobile block that can be moved only with heavy machinery or great effort)
Bollard (usually concrete or metal) pillar or pillars in the middle of the road to prevent passage by some traffic
Border Control (control point at an international border between two countries)
Cable Barrier (road side or median barrier made of steel wire ropes mounted on weak posts)
Cattle Grid (bars in the road surface that allow wheeled vehicles but not animals to cross)
Chain (chain used to prevent motorized vehicles)
City Wall (A fortification used to defend a city or settlement from potential aggressors)
Debris (road is blocked by debris with or without ground)
Ditch (trench, ditch or ravine, usually with a stream at the bottom that is not easily crossed especially if not on foot)
Fence (structure supported by posts driven into the ground and designed to prevent movement across a boundary)
Gate (entrance that can be opened or closed to get through the barrier)
Guard Rail (also called a crash barrier)
Hampshire Gate (section of wire fence which can be removed temporarily)
Hedge (Is a line of closely spaced shrubs and bushes planted and trained in such a way as to form a barrier or to mark the boundary of an area)
Jersey Barrier (consists of heavy prefabricated blocks to create a barrier)
Kerb or Curb (short solid barrier, usually found at the edge of a road, path or sidewalk, which prevents entrance by vehicles) wheelchair users
Lift Gate (bar, or pole pivoted in such a way as to allow the boom to block vehicular access through a controlled point)
Log (passage is closed by lumber, like the trunk of a tree)
Rope (flexible barrier made of fibers twisted or braided together to improve strength)
Sliding Gate (Similar to a lift gate but slides sidewards to open)
Stile (allows pedestrians to cross a wall or fence but never actually "opens" the barrier )
Unknown barrier type
Swing Gate (single or double)

input.label: Name or reference on the barrier if there is one
Please take a GPS location of this barrier

item.label: Double Wide
Single wide
Record a track while moving
Record a single point while stationary

Please record a GPS tracks while you are walking for driving
Any other comments about this feature
